Notations.
In this paper, we use \GG\GG\GG to denote a finite Abelian group and \FF\FF\FF to denote a prime field.
We also use \sample\sample\sample to denote the sampling of uniformly random elements, and denote the assignment of variables as x←4←𝑥4x\leftarrow 4.
Moreover, we use capital letter to denote a table (except for model weights and the submodel selections, which are denoted as w and s separately). We also use T​[i]𝑇delimited-[]𝑖T[i] to denote the i𝑖i-th element in the table T𝑇T
and use |⋅||\cdot| to denote the size of an element.
We summarize other notations in Table 1.

S7.T5.caption: Table 5: Computation efficiency of our basic SSA protocol (in seconds), where we let l=128𝑙128l=128, λ=128𝜆128\lambda=128, \ceil​log⁡Θ=9\ceilΘ9\ceil{\log\Theta}=9, and see table 3 for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon choices. The aggregation refers to the process that the server locally aggregates all possible evaluation results for each output.

Recall that we provide theoretical analysis of the communication efficiency of our basic protocols, and with optimisations.
In this section, we focus on the computational efficiency.
First, we adopt several optimisations from previous work, i.e.,
enabling full-domain evaluation of DPF [11] and we enable multi-threading for all our experiments.
We run our experiments with different input sizes (from 210superscript2102^{10} to 220superscript2202^{20}) with different compression rate, i.e., 10%,20%,30%percent10percent20percent3010\%,20\%,30\%.
We choose 10%∼30%similar-topercent10percent3010\%\sim 30\% compression rate because we observe that this compression range is acceptable for most federated learning tasks.
See Figure 6.
We record the the DPF key generation time for one client, and the DPF evaluation and aggregation time for each server.
All our experiments can finish within 30s when there is less than 33 million weights with 10%percent1010\% compression rate.
Second, we run our experiments with 215superscript2152^{15} weights and different compression rates, ranging from 10%percent1010\% to 100%percent100100\%.
See Figure 7 for experimental results.
For more general computational efficiency results, see Table 5.
Note that the server computation runtime is almost irrelevant to the compression rate, while the client runtime is linear to the compression rate.
In terms of communication efficiency, we run our experiments with different input sizes, ranging from 210superscript2102^{10} to 220superscript2202^{20}, and different compression rates, i.e., 1%∼10%similar-topercent1percent101\%\sim 10\% (since our basic protocol is only non-trivial in this range without scenario-specific optimisations).
See Table 6 for detailed results.

Note that the secure aggregation we refer to in the table is the naïve secure aggregation protocol in the two-server setting.

Recall that we provide theoretical analysis of the communication efficiency of our basic protocols, and with optimisations.
In this section, we focus on the computational efficiency.
First, we adopt several optimisations from previous work, i.e.,
enabling full-domain evaluation of DPF [11] and we enable multi-threading for all our experiments.
We run our experiments with different input sizes (from 210superscript2102^{10} to 220superscript2202^{20}) with different compression rate, i.e., 10%,20%,30%percent10percent20percent3010\%,20\%,30\%.
We choose 10%∼30%similar-topercent10percent3010\%\sim 30\% compression rate because we observe that this compression range is acceptable for most federated learning tasks.
See Figure 6.
We record the the DPF key generation time for one client, and the DPF evaluation and aggregation time for each server.
All our experiments can finish within 30s when there is less than 33 million weights with 10%percent1010\% compression rate.
Second, we run our experiments with 215superscript2152^{15} weights and different compression rates, ranging from 10%percent1010\% to 100%percent100100\%.
See Figure 7 for experimental results.
For more general computational efficiency results, see Table 5.
Note that the server computation runtime is almost irrelevant to the compression rate, while the client runtime is linear to the compression rate.
In terms of communication efficiency, we run our experiments with different input sizes, ranging from 210superscript2102^{10} to 220superscript2202^{20}, and different compression rates, i.e., 1%∼10%similar-topercent1percent101\%\sim 10\% (since our basic protocol is only non-trivial in this range without scenario-specific optimisations).
See Table 6 for detailed results.

S7.T7.table:
Dataset 5% 10% 20% 40% 60% 80% 100%
MNIST 97.36 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.12 97.40 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 97.43 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 97.45 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 97.47 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 97.47 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 97.47 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13
CIFAR10 58.79 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.17 59.15 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.17 59.46 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.09 59.58 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.05 59.62 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.02 59.67 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.12 59.57 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.10
TREC(iid) 88.87 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.50 89.20 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.87 89.20 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.20 89.47 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.70 89.60 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.87 89.60 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.87 89.60 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.87
references:
All accuracy results are reported with mean and standard deviation over three random runs, which are reported in Table 7.
Experimental results show that on each task, when the compression rate exceeds a certain threshold, as the compression rate increases, the final convergence accuracy of the model will experience a slight drop, which is tolerable considering that the communication cost can be reduced a lot with such top-k𝑘k submodel selection strategy. In addition, we observe that when the compression ratio reaches 50 times, the performances of the models on the MNIST, CIFAR10, and TREC datasets are only reduced by 0.11%, 0.78% and 0.73%, respectively. This demonstrates that the top-k𝑘k strategy is effective and practical for the federated learning.

S7.T8.caption: Table 8: Accuracy Experiment 2 (Basic Protocol) for FSL with Mega-Elements
S7.T8.table:
Compression Rate 0.0125% 0.1% 1% 10%
Accuracy 84.73 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.76 88.60 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.87 89.67 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.23 89.73 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.31
references:
The experimental results are shown in Table 8. Note that the compression ratio here is calculated in comparison with the parameters of the entire embedding layer instead of the entire neural network.
From the results, we can conclude that the top-k𝑘k mega-elements selection strategy is robust against a wide range of compression rate.

S7.T9.caption: Table 9: Statistics of TREC dataset.
S7.T9.table:
Type #Client (s) #Words #Samples
Test (Full) / 753 500
Train (Full) 4 8256 5452
Train (Per Client) 1 3365 1363
references:
We validated the effectiveness of top-k𝑘k (with dynamic submodels to be aggregated for each communication round)
on different datasets [1].
We consider two widely used federated image datasets MNIST[32] and CIFAR10[30] and an NLP text materials dataset TREC222Test REtrieval Conference (TREC) dataset: https://trec.nist.gov/data.html.
For the MNIST and CIFAR10 dataset, we follow the IID data partitioning strategy described in [33], where split the two datasets evenly into 100 clients after being randomly shuffled respectively. We adopt the CNN model architecture used in [33] for MNIST and CIFAR10.
As for TREC dataset, following [43], the dataset is distributed to 4 clients evenly.
The statistics of the dataset is shown in Table 9, and we adopt the same TextCNN [27] model, which is a convolutional neural network with additional embedding layer for text classification.
